A combination of skill and luck (a high batting average on balls in play) allows them to keep their average at or above .400 through the end of May.
forecast.rationale:
My forecast is based on the significant tension between a player's current reported performance and the strong statistical principle of regression to the mean. The timeframe is very shortâ€”only 13 days until the outcome is known on June 1, 2025. The key piece of information is that a major player, Aaron Judge, is reportedly at or near a .400 average as of today, May 19. This means we are not starting from zero; there is an active candidate.

Historically, several players have been at or above .400 on June 1st (e.g., Chipper Jones in 2008, Luis Arraez in 2023), so there is precedent for a 'Yes' outcome. The question's condition of 'any major league baseball player' also increases the probability compared to a question about a specific player. 

However, the status quo in baseball statistics is regression. Maintaining a .400 average is exceptionally difficult, as even a single hitless game can significantly lower the figure. It is statistically more likely than not that any player currently at .400 will see their average dip over the next two weeks of games. This is the primary reason the forecast is below 50%.

My forecast is not lower than 40% because a player has already reached the threshold with very little time remaining. This is no longer a low-probability event; it is an active, ongoing possibility. If no player were currently near .400, my forecast would be substantially lower, likely in the 10-15% range based on historical base rates.

My forecast is not higher than 40% because the statistical pull towards a player's career-average performance is relentless. To stay at .400, a player essentially needs to continue their hot streak, likely hitting over .400 for the next 13 days, which is a difficult feat. I would increase my forecast if, for example, the leading candidate's average increased over the next week or if a second player also crossed the .400 threshold. Conversely, I would lower it if the leading candidate had a few poor games and dropped significantly below the mark.
